title: Histology: Part 1
subject: Histology
description: Questions about the histology of the central nervous system and spinal cord

questions.questionText: Which of the following is NOT a part of the brain in the central nervous system?
questions.explanation: The central nervous system includes the brain (cerebrum, cerebellum, diencephalon, brainstem) and the spinal cord separately.

questions.questionText: How many segments does the spinal cord have?
questions.explanation: The spinal cord has 31 segments: cervical 8, thoracic 12, lumbar 5, sacral 5, and coccygeal 1.

questions.questionText: Which general character of the CNS explains its soft jelly-like consistency?
options: Consists of white and grey matter
questions.explanation: The CNS is soft jelly-like because it does not contain connective tissue.

questions.questionText: In a cross-section of the spinal cord, what shape does the central grey matter typically form?
questions.explanation: The central grey matter in the spinal cord cross-section is H-shaped.

questions.questionText: What components primarily form the grey matter of the spinal cord?
options: Myelinated nerve fibers and neuroglial cells
Nerve cells, neuroglial cells, and unmyelinated nerve fibers
questions.correctAnswer: Nerve cells, neuroglial cells, and unmyelinated nerve fibers
questions.explanation: Grey matter is formed of nerve cells, neuroglial cells, and unmyelinated nerve fibers.

questions.questionText: The dorsal horns of the spinal cord grey matter contain which type of nuclei?
questions.explanation: The two dorsal horns contain sensory nuclei.

questions.questionText: In which segments of the spinal cord are the lateral horns present?
questions.explanation: Additional two lateral horns are only in thoracic and upper 2 lumbar segments containing sympathetic nuclei.

questions.questionText: What is the definition of a nucleus in the context of the CNS?
options: A group of myelinated fibers with the same function
A group of nerve cells inside CNS having the same function
questions.correctAnswer: A group of nerve cells inside CNS having the same function
questions.explanation: A nucleus is a group of nerve cells inside the CNS having the same function.

questions.questionText: Which nucleus is found in the posterior horns at all levels of the spinal cord?
questions.explanation: Substantia Gelatinosa of Rolandi (SGR) is a sensory nucleus in posterior horns at all levels.

questions.questionText: How many fixed nuclei are present in all levels of the spinal cord?
questions.explanation: Fixed nuclei in all levels: SGR, MSN, Ant. Commissural, Post. Commissural, Ant. Med. Motor, Post Med. Motor.

questions.questionText: What primarily forms the white matter of the spinal cord?
options: Neuroglial cells and myelinated nerve fibers
questions.correctAnswer: Neuroglial cells and myelinated nerve fibers
questions.explanation: White matter is formed of neuroglial cells and myelinated nerve fibers.

questions.questionText: Into how many columns is the white matter divided in each half of the spinal cord?
questions.explanation: It is divided into 3 columns in each half: dorsal, lateral, anterior.

questions.questionText: Which column of the white matter contains only ascending tracts?
questions.explanation: Posterior Column contains ascending tracts only.

questions.questionText: What is the definition of a tract in the CNS?
options: A group of nerve cells with the same function
A group of nerve fibers inside CNS with same beginning, end, and function
questions.correctAnswer: A group of nerve fibers inside CNS with same beginning, end, and function
questions.explanation: A tract is a group of nerve fibers inside the CNS with the same beginning, end, and function.

questions.questionText: Short tracts of the spinal cord are characterized as:
questions.explanation: Short tracts are both ascending and descending, while long tracts are ascending or descending.
